<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:readtime" content="7"/>
<meta property="og:views" content="44,660"/>
<meta property="og:date_created" content="July 8, 2016 at 5:00 AM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="1758"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Research"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Josh Grunzweig"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/joshgruznweig/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="ConfuserEx,LuminosityLink,Remote Access Trojan,Trojan"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Investigating the LuminosityLink Remote Access Trojan Configuration","name":"Investigating the LuminosityLink Remote Access Trojan Configuration","description":"In recent weeks, I\u2019ve spent time investigating the LuminosityLink Remote Access Trojan\u2019s (RAT) embedded configuration. For those unaware, LuminosityLink is a malware family costing $40 that purports to be a system administration utility. However, when executed, the malware leverages a very aggressive keylogger, as well as a number of other malicious features that allow an","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration\/","datePublished":"July 8, 2016","articleBody":"In recent weeks, I\u2019ve spent time investigating the LuminosityLink Remote Access Trojan\u2019s (RAT) embedded configuration. For those unaware, LuminosityLink is a malware family costing $40 that purports to be a system administration utility. However, when executed, the malware leverages a very aggressive keylogger, as well as a number of other malicious features that allow an attacker to gain full control over a victim machine.\n\n\nFigure 1 LuminosityLink website\nAt the request of a coworker, I was asked to extract the configuration of a LuminosityLink sample, and while I could have simply executed the malware in a sandboxed environment and pulled the configuration from memory, I chose to see if I could perform the same action against the static binary.\n\nThis led to me understanding how the configuration is encrypted within the binary, as well as how to parse that configuration. I\u2019ve created a script to perform this action against an unaltered LuminosityLink malware sample, which I will be sharing within this blog post. Furthermore, I looked at the roughly 18,000 LuminosityLink samples Palo Alto Networks has collected over time, and using this script, I was able to extract the configurations of 14,700 samples. (This data can be found in the Appendix section of this post.)\nOverview of LuminosityLink\nOriginally surfacing in May 2015, LuminosityLink\u2019s popularity has been on the rise, as shown in the following chart. To date, Palo Alto Networks has tracked approximately 50,000 attempted infections of LuminosityLink against our customers.\n\n\nFigure 2 AutoFocus graph of LuminosityLink sessions over time.\nLuminosityLink currently sells for $40 and can be purchased directly from its author. This package allows attackers to host a LuminosityLink server as well as generate customized binaries, which are obfuscated with ConfuserEx 0.4.0. ConfuserEx is an open-source project that obfuscates the underlying .NET code, making it much more difficult for reverse engineers that decompile it. This is important to note for later when we discuss determining how to reverse-engineer the encryption process.\n\nAs mentioned previously, a number of configuration options are included, as we can see in the following screenshot.\n\n\nFigure 3 Client configuration options in LuminosityLink\nOnce executed, attackers are given a wealth of options, including keylogging, remote desktop, password stealing, and interacting with a shell on the device.\nReverse-Engineering the Configuration\nThe first step in parsing out the configuration of LuminosityLink is to extract it statically. I initially opened up a clean LuminosityLink sample using a program named dnSpy to search for clues as to where the configuration might be stored. (As a quick aside, I highly recommend dnSpy, as it not only does a great job of decompiling the provided .NET binary, but it also comes equipped with a built-in debugger, which is instrumental in tackling problems such as the one we are facing.)\n\nWhen initially opening up a sample binary, I didn\u2019t expect much as I knew the sample was obfuscated using ConfuserEx. However, looking at the resources of the sample, I saw some strings that looked promising.\n\n\nFigure 4 Embedded resource strings in LuminosityLink\nAs we can see, the malware contains a number of resources that in turn contain what appears to be Base64-encoded data. The \u201cSMARTLOGS\u201d, \u201cXML\u201d, and \u201cCONFIG\u201d resources all contain a wealth of data, which, at this point, is still unknown. Unfortunately, decoding these strings results in garbage, which likely means some other form of encryption is being used underneath.\n\nI continued to investigate the underlying code, which, while obfuscated, still provides a high-level idea of what various classes are doing. Using imported namespaces, API calls and certain un-obfuscated strings, we\u2019re able to get clues as to what is going on within the program. Specifically, we see the fd() class using the namespace of \u2018System.Security.Cryptography\u2019, which certainly merits investigation as we suspected crypto being used against the earlier referenced resource strings.\n\n\nFigure 5 Cryptography namespace being used by LuminosityLink\nAs we further investigate this class, we see references to the following classes and functions:\n\n \tMD5CryptoServiceProvider\n \tComputeHash\n \tFromBase64String\n \tRijndaelManaged\n\nAt this point, I turned to my debugger in an attempt to see how these strings were handled. I set breakpoints on various calls previously mentioned. Specifically, the breakpoint on the RijndaelManaged class yields excellent results.\n\n\nFigure 6 Successful recovery of AES-128 key\nWe\u2019re able to not only verify that AES-128 encryption is used, but also verify that the \u201cSMARTLOGS\u201d resource string is being used. We also are able to identify the string being used as the key, which in this particular example is \u201c\\\\ecnOnuR\\\\noisreVtnerruC\\\\swodniW\\\\tfosorciM\\\\erawtfoS\u201d. Further investigation reveals that this string is hashed using the MD5 algorithm. The first 15 bytes of this hash is concatenated with the entire 16 bytes of the hash, followed by a null byte. We can replicate this decryption process in Python as such:\ndef decrypt_data(data, key_string):\n\tdecoded_data = base64.b64decode(data)\n\tm = hashlib.md5()\n\tm.update(key_string)\n\tmd5 = m.digest()\n\tkey = md5[0:15]+md5+\"\\x00\"\n\tmode = AES.MODE_ECB\n\tiv = '\\x00' * 16\n\te = AES.new(key, mode, iv)\n\treturn e.decrypt(decoded_data)\nWe can further verify that this is correct using the above code. In the following example, the data variable has been set with the base64-encoded string found within the \u201cSMARTLOGS\u201d resource, and the key_string variable has been set to the reversed registry key previously mentioned.\n&gt;&gt;&gt; print decrypt_data(data, key_string)\n172.16.1.100|11111|backup.dns.com|filename.exe|startup_name|folder_name|data_directory_name|backup_startup.exe|df5e0e1c667c399588b014cb9b4ae7b33c9c0b4cac9d4169f39197e41e9a43a4|BuildID|1idsnb|\nUsing trial and error, we\u2019re able to successfully map each variable witnessed in the above configuration. The last variable proves to be quite interesting, as each character except for \u20181\u2019 maps to a particular configuration option. The following mapping was determined:\n\n \ti : Enable Client Installation\/Startup\n \td : Client Persistence Module: Protect Luminosity's Client Binary\n \ts : Silent Mode (Hide Luminosity Window on Client PC)\n \ta : Proactive Anti-Malware: Clean Malicious Files and Speed up Client PC\n \tn : Power Saver: Prevent Sleep Mode and Turn off Monitor after 15 minutes of inactivity\n \tm : Remove File after Execution (Melt)\n \tv : Anti-Virtual Machines\/Debugging\n \th : Hide File and Directories\n \tb : Backup Startup\n\nUsing this knowledge, we can parse the above configuration, which yields the following results.\nDomain\/IP:            172.16.1.100\nPort:                 11111\nBackup DNS:           backup.dns.com\nFilename:             filename.exe\nStartup Name:         startup_name\nFolder Name:          folder_name\nData Directory Name:  data_directory_name\nBackup Startup Exe:   backup_startup.exe\nMutex:                df5e0e1c667c399588b014cb9b4ae7b33c9c0b4cac9d4169f39197e41e9a43a4\nBuild ID:             BuildID\nSettings:\n  [X] Enable Client Installation\/Startup\n  [X] Client Persistence Module: Protect Luminosity's Client Binary\n  [X] Silent Mode (Hide Luminosity Window on Client PC)\n  [ ] Proactive Anti-Malware: Clean Malicious Files and Speed up Client PC\n  [X] Power Saver: Prevent Sleep Mode and Turn off Monitor after 15 minutes of inactivity\n  [ ] Remove File after Execution (Melt)\n  [ ] Anti-Virtual Machines\/Debugging\n  [ ] Hide File and Directories\n  [X] Backup Startup\n\nParsing LuminosityLink Configurations at Scale\nUsing this knowledge, we created a script to parse the configuration of a given sample. The script searches for strings that appear to be base64-encoded with a length greater than 50 and takes a brute-force approach. While not elegant, it does the job quite successfully. The script can be downloaded in the Appendix section of this blog post.\n\nGoing through Palo Alto Networks repository of samples, we found roughly 18,000 files tagged as LuminosityLink. For these 18,000 samples, we applied our static configuration extraction and parsing script and successfully retrieved about 4,500 configurations. The remaining samples were packed beyond the built-in ConfuserEx obfuscation routine, and as such, the raw configuration strings were not present.\n\nThese samples were run through a local instance of the open-source Cuckoo Sandbox, where the process dumps were extracted. The same script was applied to these process dumps, where we were able to obtain an additional 10,200 configurations, leaving us with a total of 14,700 parsed LuminosityLink configurations.\n\nAs the samples were processed, further keys were discovered to be used by the author. The following additional three strings were used to generate the keys to LuminosityLink samples.\n\n \tThis conf'ig contains nothing useful. Quit acting as if you're cool by decrypting it.\n \tResources.SMARTLOGS\n \tSpecify a Password\n\nIt appears as though the author of LuminosityLink is not without a sense of humor. Additionally, as we parsed older samples, it was discovered that the configuration made a change sometime between February and June of this year. Fewer options were available in the configuration of older samples. The provided script accounts for these differences and various keys used.\n\nUsing the aggregated data from the 14,700 configurations, the following high-level statistics were pulled:\n\n\nFigure 7 Prevalence of enabled settings in LuminosityLink configurations\n\nTop C2 TLDs\/IP Addresses\n\n \t[3308] ddns[.]net\n \t[2537] duckdns[.]org\n \t[904] no-ip[.]biz\n \t[670] chickenkiller[.]com\n \t[378] no-ip[.]org\n \t[377] mooo[.]com\n \t[242] fishdns[.]com\n \t[174] no-ip[.]info\n \t[165] ignorelist[.]com\n \t[157] freedns[.]su\n\nTop Build IDs\n\n \t[4829] HOME\n \t[83]\u00a0\u00a0 Client\n \t[82]\u00a0\u00a0 crtx1\n \t[71]\u00a0\u00a0 M4CHINATION\n \t[65]\u00a0\u00a0 CSGO\n \t[65]\u00a0\u00a0 NEW\n \t[59]\u00a0\u00a0 Slave\n \t[47]\u00a0\u00a0 CAPO\n \t[44]\u00a0\u00a0 Youtube\n \t[42]\u00a0\u00a0 PROJECT.D\n\nTop Executable Names\n\n \t[1973] sysmon.exe\n \t[1831] client.exe\n \t[1254] helper.exe\n \t[1207] repair.exe\n \t[1087] winlogon.exe\n \t[509] svchost.exe\n \t[315] Luminosity.exe\n \t[83]\u00a0\u00a0 WinCOMHost.exe\n \t[82]\u00a0\u00a0 chrome.exe\n \t[61]\u00a0\u00a0 windowsbootapp.exe\n\nTop Ports\n\n \t[1866] 6318\n \t[1055] 1400\n \t[493] 1604\n \t[412] 1337\n \t[214] 3175\n \t[182] 22028\n \t[162] 9045\n \t[119] 2122\n \t[115] 100\n \t[113] 9999\n\nThe parsed configuration data, provided in the CSV file format, is being freely provided to the security community in the hope that protections will be created against this threat.\nConclusion\nLuminosityLink, while marketed as a systems administration utility, is a formidable keylogger and backdoor used by a large number of criminals. To date, Palo Alto Networks has witnessed over 50,000 attempted infections of LuminosityLink, encompassing 18,000 unique samples. The malware is cheap and readily available to the public, making this a dangerous threat to both organizations and individuals alike.\n\nBy reverse-engineering LuminosityLink samples, we were able to statically extract and parse the embedded configuration, which in turn provides valuable information about with what hosts and ports the malware is configured to communicate. It also provides information regarding configured protections configured within the executable, as well as installation information.\n\nPalo Alto Networks customers are protected from this threat in the following ways:\n\nAn AutoFocus tag can be used to track this malware family\n\n \tAll LuminosityLink samples are appropriately marked as malicious in WildFire\n \tAll identified domains are flagged as malicious\n \tNetwork traffic is appropriately identified and blocked as threat ID #14460 (LumonosityLinkRAT.Gen Command And Control Traffic)\n\nAppendix\nAn extraction and parsing script for LuminosityLink samples can be found here.\n\nA script to be used to parse plain configuration strings can be found here.\n\nA CSV file containing all of the configuration data extracted from Palo Alto Networks sample set can be found here.","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"","width":"","height":""},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Josh Grunzweig"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-theme-classic-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/themes/classic/classic.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-font-monaco-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/fonts/monaco.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(238,238,238) 0%,rgb(169,184,195) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--cool-to-warm-spectrum: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(74,234,220) 0%,rgb(151,120,209) 20%,rgb(207,42,186) 40%,rgb(238,44,130) 60%,rgb(251,105,98) 80%,rgb(254,248,76) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--blush-light-purple: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(255,206,236) 0%,rgb(152,150,240) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--blush-bordeaux: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(254,205,165) 0%,rgb(254,45,45) 50%,rgb(107,0,62) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--luminous-dusk: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(255,203,112) 0%,rgb(199,81,192) 50%,rgb(65,88,208) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--pale-ocean: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(255,245,203) 0%,rgb(182,227,212) 50%,rgb(51,167,181) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--electric-grass: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(202,248,128) 0%,rgb(113,206,126) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--midnight: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(2,3,129) 0%,rgb(40,116,252) 100%);--wp--preset--font-size--small: 13px;--wp--preset--font-size--medium: 20px;--wp--preset--font-size--large: 36px;--wp--preset--font-size--x-large: 42px;--wp--preset--spacing--20: 0.44rem;--wp--preset--spacing--30: 0.67rem;--wp--preset--spacing--40: 1rem;--wp--preset--spacing--50: 1.5rem;--wp--preset--spacing--60: 2.25rem;--wp--preset--spacing--70: 3.38rem;--wp--preset--spacing--80: 5.06rem;--wp--preset--shadow--natural: 6px 6px 9px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);--wp--preset--shadow--deep: 12px 12px 50px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);--wp--preset--shadow--sharp: 6px     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */

/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x

</script>

        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>
</div>
</div>
<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">

          <div class="l-container">

					<span class="icon-globe"></span>
					<span>English</span>
					<span class="icon-down"></span>
				  </a>

				</li>

				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p>In recent weeks, Ive spent time investigating the LuminosityLink Remote Access Trojans (RAT) embedded configuration. For those unaware, LuminosityLink is a malware family costing $40 that purports to be a system administration utility. However, when executed, the malware leverages a very aggressive keylogger, as well as a number of other malicious features that allow an attacker to gain full control over a victim machine.<span id="more-15421"></span></p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-1/" rel="attachment wp-att-15424"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15424 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-1-500x285.png" alt="LuminosityLink 1" width="500" height="285" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 1 LuminosityLink website</em></p>
<p>At the request of a coworker, I was asked to extract the configuration of a LuminosityLink sample, and while I could have simply executed the malware in a sandboxed environment and pulled the configuration from memory, I chose to see if I could perform the same action against the static binary.</p>
<p>This led to me understanding how the configuration is encrypted within the binary, as well as how to parse that configuration. Ive created a script to perform this action against an unaltered LuminosityLink malware sample, which I will be sharing within this blog post. Furthermore, I looked at the roughly 18,000 LuminosityLink samples Palo Alto Networks has collected over time, and using this script, I was able to extract the configurations of 14,700 samples. (This data can be found in the Appendix section of this post.)</p>
<h3>Overview of LuminosityLink</h3>
<p>Originally surfacing in May 2015, LuminosityLinks popularity has been on the rise, as shown in the following chart. To date, Palo Alto Networks has tracked approximately 50,000 attempted infections of LuminosityLink against our customers.</p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-15427"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15427 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-2-500x110.png" alt="LuminosityLink 2" width="500" height="110" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 2 AutoFocus graph of LuminosityLink sessions over time.</em></p>
<p>LuminosityLink currently sells for $40 and can be purchased directly from its author. This package allows attackers to host a LuminosityLink server as well as generate customized binaries, which are obfuscated with ConfuserEx 0.4.0. ConfuserEx is an open-source project that obfuscates the underlying .NET code, making it much more difficult for reverse engineers that decompile it. This is important to note for later when we discuss determining how to reverse-engineer the encryption process.</p>
<p>As mentioned previously, a number of configuration options are included, as we can see in the following screenshot.</p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-3/" rel="attachment wp-att-15430"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15430 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-3-500x266.png" alt="LuminosityLink 3" width="500" height="266" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 3 Client configuration options in LuminosityLink</em></p>
<p>Once executed, attackers are given a wealth of options, including keylogging, remote desktop, password stealing, and interacting with a shell on the device.</p>
<h3>Reverse-Engineering the Configuration</h3>
<p>The first step in parsing out the configuration of LuminosityLink is to extract it statically. I initially opened up a clean LuminosityLink sample using a program named <a href="https://github.com/0xd4d/dnSpy" target="_blank">dnSpy</a> to search for clues as to where the configuration might be stored. (As a quick aside, I highly recommend dnSpy, as it not only does a great job of decompiling the provided .NET binary, but it also comes equipped with a built-in debugger, which is instrumental in tackling problems such as the one we are facing.)</p>
<p>When initially opening up a sample binary, I didnt expect much as I knew the sample was obfuscated using ConfuserEx. However, looking at the resources of the sample, I saw some strings that looked promising.</p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-4/" rel="attachment wp-att-15433"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15433 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-4-500x246.png" alt="LuminosityLink 4" width="500" height="246" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 4 Embedded resource strings in LuminosityLink</em></p>
<p>As we can see, the malware contains a number of resources that in turn contain what appears to be Base64-encoded data. The SMARTLOGS, XML, and CONFIG resources all contain a wealth of data, which, at this point, is still unknown. Unfortunately, decoding these strings results in garbage, which likely means some other form of encryption is being used underneath.</p>
<p>I continued to investigate the underlying code, which, while obfuscated, still provides a high-level idea of what various classes are doing. Using imported namespaces, API calls and certain un-obfuscated strings, were able to get clues as to what is going on within the program. Specifically, we see the fd() class using the namespace of System.Security.Cryptography, which certainly merits investigation as we suspected crypto being used against the earlier referenced resource strings.</p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-5/" rel="attachment wp-att-15436"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15436 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-5-500x270.png" alt="LuminosityLink 5" width="500" height="270" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 5 Cryptography namespace being used by LuminosityLink</em></p>
<p>As we further investigate this class, we see references to the following classes and functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>MD5CryptoServiceProvider</li>
<li>ComputeHash</li>
<li>FromBase64String</li>
<li>RijndaelManaged</li>
</ul>
<p>At this point, I turned to my debugger in an attempt to see how these strings were handled. I set breakpoints on various calls previously mentioned. Specifically, the breakpoint on the RijndaelManaged class yields excellent results.</p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-6/" rel="attachment wp-att-15439"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15439 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-6-500x281.png" alt="LuminosityLink 6" width="500" height="281" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 6 Successful recovery of AES-128 key</em></p>
<p>Were able to not only verify that AES-128 encryption is used, but also verify that the SMARTLOGS resource string is being used. We also are able to identify the string being used as the key, which in this particular example is \\ecnOnuR\\noisreVtnerruC\\swodniW\\tfosorciM\\erawtfoS. Further investigation reveals that this string is hashed using the MD5 algorithm. The first 15 bytes of this hash is concatenated with the entire 16 bytes of the hash, followed by a null byte. We can replicate this decryption process in Python as such:</p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
def decrypt_data(data, key_string):
	decoded_data = base64.b64decode(data)
	m = hashlib.md5()
	m.update(key_string)
	md5 = m.digest()
	key = md5[0:15]+md5+"\x00"
	mode = AES.MODE_ECB
	iv = '\x00' * 16
	e = AES.new(key, mode, iv)
	return e.decrypt(decoded_data)</textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-2">2</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-3">3</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-4">4</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-5">5</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-6">6</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-7">7</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-8">8</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-9">9</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-10">10</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-1"><span class="crayon-e">def </span><span class="crayon-e">decrypt_data</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">data</span><span class="crayon-sy">,</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">key_string</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-2"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">decoded_data</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">base64</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">b64decode</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">data</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-3"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">m</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">hashlib</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">md5</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-4"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">m</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">update</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">key_string</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-5"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">md5</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">m</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">digest</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-6"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">key</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">md5</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-cn">0</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-cn">15</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span>+<span class="crayon-i">md5</span>+<span class="crayon-s">"\x00"</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-7"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">mode</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">AES</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">MODE_ECB</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-8"><span class="crayon-e">	</span><span class="crayon-i">iv</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">'\x00'</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>*<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">16</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-9"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-i">e</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">AES</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">new</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">key</span><span class="crayon-sy">,</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">mode</span><span class="crayon-sy">,</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">iv</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbff2887607970-10"><span class="crayon-h">	</span><span class="crayon-st">return</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">e</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">decrypt</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">decoded_data</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0002 seconds] -->
<p>We can further verify that this is correct using the above code. In the following example, the data variable has been set with the base64-encoded string found within the SMARTLOGS resource, and the key_string variable has been set to the reversed registry key previously mentioned.</p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-67e61e9bbbffc369829051" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
&gt;&gt;&gt; print decrypt_data(data, key_string)
172.16.1.100|11111|backup.dns.com|filename.exe|startup_name|folder_name|data_directory_name|backup_startup.exe|df5e0e1c667c399588b014cb9b4ae7b33c9c0b4cac9d4169f39197e41e9a43a4|BuildID|1idsnb|</textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbffc369829051-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbffc369829051-2">2</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbffc369829051-1"><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">print </span><span class="crayon-e">decrypt_data</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">data</span><span class="crayon-sy">,</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">key_string</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbffc369829051-2"><span class="crayon-cn">172.16.1.100</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-cn">11111</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">backup</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">dns</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">com</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">filename</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">exe</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">startup_name</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">folder_name</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">data_directory_name</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">backup_startup</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">exe</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">df5e0e1c667c399588b014cb9b4ae7b33c9c0b4cac9d4169f39197e41e9a43a4</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">BuildID</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-cn">1idsnb</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span></div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0001 seconds] -->
<p>Using trial and error, were able to successfully map each variable witnessed in the above configuration. The last variable proves to be quite interesting, as each character except for 1 maps to a particular configuration option. The following mapping was determined:</p>
<ul>
<li><em>i : Enable Client Installation/Startup</em></li>
<li><em>d : Client Persistence Module: Protect Luminosity's Client Binary</em></li>
<li><em>s : Silent Mode (Hide Luminosity Window on Client PC)</em></li>
<li><em>a : Proactive Anti-Malware: Clean Malicious Files and Speed up Client PC</em></li>
<li><em>n : Power Saver: Prevent Sleep Mode and Turn off Monitor after 15 minutes of inactivity</em></li>
<li><em>m : Remove File after Execution (Melt)</em></li>
<li><em>v : Anti-Virtual Machines/Debugging</em></li>
<li><em>h : Hide File and Directories</em></li>
<li><em>b : Backup Startup</em></li>
</ul>
<p>Using this knowledge, we can parse the above configuration, which yields the following results.</p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
Domain/IP:            172.16.1.100
Port:                 11111
Backup DNS:           backup.dns.com
Filename:             filename.exe
Startup Name:         startup_name
Folder Name:          folder_name
Data Directory Name:  data_directory_name
Backup Startup Exe:   backup_startup.exe
Mutex:                df5e0e1c667c399588b014cb9b4ae7b33c9c0b4cac9d4169f39197e41e9a43a4
Build ID:             BuildID
Settings:
  [X] Enable Client Installation/Startup
  [X] Client Persistence Module: Protect Luminosity's Client Binary
  [X] Silent Mode (Hide Luminosity Window on Client PC)
  [ ] Proactive Anti-Malware: Clean Malicious Files and Speed up Client PC
  [X] Power Saver: Prevent Sleep Mode and Turn off Monitor after 15 minutes of inactivity
  [ ] Remove File after Execution (Melt)
  [ ] Anti-Virtual Machines/Debugging
  [ ] Hide File and Directories
  [X] Backup Startup</textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-2">2</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-3">3</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-4">4</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-5">5</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-6">6</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-7">7</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-8">8</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-9">9</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-10">10</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-11">11</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-12">12</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-13">13</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-14">14</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-15">15</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-16">16</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-17">17</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-18">18</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-19">19</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-20">20</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-1"><span class="crayon-i">Domain</span>/<span class="crayon-i">IP</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-cn">172.16.1.100</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-2"><span class="crayon-i">Port</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span class="crayon-cn">11111</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-3"><span class="crayon-e">Backup </span><span class="crayon-i">DNS</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span class="crayon-i">backup</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-i">dns</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">com</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-4"><span class="crayon-i">Filename</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span class="crayon-i">filename</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">exe</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-5"><span class="crayon-e">Startup </span><span class="crayon-i">Name</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span class="crayon-e">startup_name</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-6"><span class="crayon-e">Folder </span><span class="crayon-i">Name</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-e">folder_name</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-7"><span class="crayon-e">Data </span><span class="crayon-e">Directory </span><span class="crayon-i">Name</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-e">data_directory_name</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-8"><span class="crayon-e">Backup </span><span class="crayon-e">Startup </span><span class="crayon-i">Exe</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span class="crayon-i">backup_startup</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span><span class="crayon-e">exe</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-9"><span class="crayon-i">Mutex</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-e">df5e0e1c667c399588b014cb9b4ae7b33c9c0b4cac9d4169f39197e41e9a43a4</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-10"><span class="crayon-e">Build </span><span class="crayon-i">ID</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span class="crayon-e">BuildID</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-11"><span class="crayon-i">Settings</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-12"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">X</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Enable </span><span class="crayon-e">Client </span><span class="crayon-i">Installation</span>/<span class="crayon-i">Startup</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-13"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">X</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Client </span><span class="crayon-e">Persistence </span><span class="crayon-i">Module</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Protect </span><span class="crayon-i">Luminosity</span>'<span class="crayon-i">s</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Client </span><span class="crayon-i">Binary</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-14"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">X</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Silent </span><span class="crayon-e">Mode</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-e">Hide </span><span class="crayon-e">Luminosity </span><span class="crayon-e">Window </span><span class="crayon-e">on </span><span class="crayon-e">Client </span><span class="crayon-i">PC</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-15"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Proactive </span><span class="crayon-i">Anti</span>-<span class="crayon-i">Malware</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Clean </span><span class="crayon-e">Malicious </span><span class="crayon-e">Files </span><span class="crayon-st">and</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Speed </span><span class="crayon-e">up </span><span class="crayon-e">Client </span><span class="crayon-i">PC</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-16"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">X</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Power </span><span class="crayon-i">Saver</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Prevent </span><span class="crayon-e">Sleep </span><span class="crayon-e">Mode </span><span class="crayon-st">and</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Turn </span><span class="crayon-e">off </span><span class="crayon-e">Monitor </span><span class="crayon-i">after</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">15</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">minutes </span><span class="crayon-e">of </span><span class="crayon-i">inactivity</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-17"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Remove </span><span class="crayon-e">File </span><span class="crayon-e">after </span><span class="crayon-e">Execution</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">Melt</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-18"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">Anti</span>-<span class="crayon-e">Virtual </span><span class="crayon-i">Machines</span>/<span class="crayon-i">Debugging</span></div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-19"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Hide </span><span class="crayon-e">File </span><span class="crayon-st">and</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">Directories</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-67e61e9bbbfff468585269-20"><span class="crayon-h">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">X</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">Backup </span><span class="crayon-i">Startup</span></div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0004 seconds] -->
<p></p>
<h3>Parsing LuminosityLink Configurations at Scale</h3>
<p>Using this knowledge, we created a script to parse the configuration of a given sample. The script searches for strings that appear to be base64-encoded with a length greater than 50 and takes a brute-force approach. While not elegant, it does the job quite successfully. The script can be downloaded in the Appendix section of this blog post.</p>
<p>Going through Palo Alto Networks repository of samples, we found roughly 18,000 files tagged as LuminosityLink. For these 18,000 samples, we applied our static configuration extraction and parsing script and successfully retrieved about 4,500 configurations. The remaining samples were packed beyond the built-in ConfuserEx obfuscation routine, and as such, the raw configuration strings were not present.</p>
<p>These samples were run through a local instance of the open-source Cuckoo Sandbox, where the process dumps were extracted. The same script was applied to these process dumps, where we were able to obtain an additional 10,200 configurations, leaving us with a total of 14,700 parsed LuminosityLink configurations.</p>
<p>As the samples were processed, further keys were discovered to be used by the author. The following additional three strings were used to generate the keys to LuminosityLink samples.</p>
<ul>
<li>This conf'ig contains nothing useful. Quit acting as if you're cool by decrypting it.</li>
<li>Resources.SMARTLOGS</li>
<li>Specify a Password</li>
</ul>
<p>It appears as though the author of LuminosityLink is not without a sense of humor. Additionally, as we parsed older samples, it was discovered that the configuration made a change sometime between February and June of this year. Fewer options were available in the configuration of older samples. The provided script accounts for these differences and various keys used.</p>
<p>Using the aggregated data from the 14,700 configurations, the following high-level statistics were pulled:</p>
<p><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/07/unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration/luminositylink-7/" rel="attachment wp-att-15442"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-15442 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/LuminosityLink-7-500x149.png" alt="LuminosityLink 7" width="500" height="149" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Figure 7 Prevalence of enabled settings in LuminosityLink configurations</em></p>
<h4>Top C2 TLDs/IP Addresses</h4>
<ul>
<li>[3308] ddns[.]net</li>
<li>[2537] duckdns[.]org</li>
<li>[904] no-ip[.]biz</li>
<li>[670] chickenkiller[.]com</li>
<li>[378] no-ip[.]org</li>
<li>[377] mooo[.]com</li>
<li>[242] fishdns[.]com</li>
<li>[174] no-ip[.]info</li>
<li>[165] ignorelist[.]com</li>
<li>[157] freedns[.]su</li>
</ul>
<h4>Top Build IDs</h4>
<ul>
<li>[4829] HOME</li>
<li>[83] Client</li>
<li>[82] crtx1</li>
<li>[71] M4CHINATION</li>
<li>[65] CSGO</li>
<li>[65] NEW</li>
<li>[59] Slave</li>
<li>[47] CAPO</li>
<li>[44] Youtube</li>
<li>[42] PROJECT.D</li>
</ul>
<h4>Top Executable Names</h4>
<ul>
<li>[1973] sysmon.exe</li>
<li>[1831] client.exe</li>
<li>[1254] helper.exe</li>
<li>[1207] repair.exe</li>
<li>[1087] winlogon.exe</li>
<li>[509] svchost.exe</li>
<li>[315] Luminosity.exe</li>
<li>[83] WinCOMHost.exe</li>
<li>[82] chrome.exe</li>
<li>[61] windowsbootapp.exe</li>
</ul>
<h4>Top Ports</h4>
<ul>
<li>[1866] 6318</li>
<li>[1055] 1400</li>
<li>[493] 1604</li>
<li>[412] 1337</li>
<li>[214] 3175</li>
<li>[182] 22028</li>
<li>[162] 9045</li>
<li>[119] 2122</li>
<li>[115] 100</li>
<li>[113] 9999</li>
</ul>
<p>The parsed configuration data, provided in the CSV file format, is being freely provided to the security community in the hope that protections will be created against this threat.</p>
<h3>Conclusion</h3>
<p>LuminosityLink, while marketed as a systems administration utility, is a formidable keylogger and backdoor used by a large number of criminals. To date, Palo Alto Networks has witnessed over 50,000 attempted infections of LuminosityLink, encompassing 18,000 unique samples. The malware is cheap and readily available to the public, making this a dangerous threat to both organizations and individuals alike.</p>
<p>By reverse-engineering LuminosityLink samples, we were able to statically extract and parse the embedded configuration, which in turn provides valuable information about with what hosts and ports the malware is configured to communicate. It also provides information regarding configured protections configured within the executable, as well as installation information.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are protected from this threat in the following ways:</p>
<p>An <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/" target="_blank">AutoFocus tag</a> can be used to track this malware family</p>
<ul>
<li>All LuminosityLink samples are appropriately marked as malicious in WildFire</li>
<li>All identified domains are flagged as malicious</li>
<li>Network traffic is appropriately identified and blocked as threat ID #14460 (LumonosityLinkRAT.Gen Command And Control Traffic)</li>
</ul>
<h3>Appendix</h3>
<p>An extraction and parsing script for LuminosityLink samples can be found <a href="https://github.com/pan-unit42/public_tools/tree/master/luminositylink/parse_config_file.py" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>
<p>A script to be used to parse plain configuration strings can be found <a href="https://github.com/pan-unit42/public_tools/tree/master/luminositylink/parse_config_string.py" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>
<p>A CSV file containing all of the configuration data extracted from Palo Alto Networks sample set can be found <a href="https://github.com/pan-unit42/iocs/tree/master/luminositylink/luminositylink_configs.csv" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 1 November, 2018 at 12:16 PM PDT</span>-->

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration:related-resources:Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-03-14T10:00:04+00:00">March 14, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unusual-malware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration:related-resources:Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/net/" title=".NET" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration:related-resources:Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware:.NET">.NET</a>

                    <h4 class="post-title">Auto-Color: An Emerging and Evasive Linux Backdoor</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/linux/" title="Linux" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration:related-resources:Auto-Color: An Emerging and Evasive Linux Backdoor:Linux">Linux</a>

				</li></ul>                </div>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="292" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1616x600-1-786x292.png" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of APT Stately Taurus. The silhouette of a bull and the Taurus constellation inside an orange abstract planet. Abstract, stylized cosmic setting with vibrant blue and purple shapes, representing space and distant planetary bodies." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1616x600-1-786x292.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1616x600-1-768x285.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1616x600-1-1536x570.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1616x600-1.png 1616w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-02-20T11:00:23+00:00">February 20, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-uses-bookworm-malware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-investigating-the-luminositylink-remote-access-trojan-configuration:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware">
